I love me a good riddle, so after I filled in the three theme answers, having left the reveal blank and not reading its clue, I stopped the fill-in and started trying to crack the big question: What did those four answers have in common?

It turns out that all I had to do was focus on the first two, finding a Greek god in the NATO alphabet.  That never occurred to me.  But oh, the places I went! First letters of the theme answer words, commonalities among the last words, descriptors of the Grand Canyon ‚Ä¶ 

The point is my brain was pinballing all over the place, looking at letters and words, visualizing warehouses and canyons, and spending much time, to paraphrase one of the puzzle‚Äôs answers, going, ‚ÄúWA?‚Äù ‚ÄúWA?‚Äù

Finally, I uncle-d, having been gotten good, read the revealer‚Äôs clue, and immediately underwent an aha moment for the ages that included the mighty riddle-crack, awe over the brilliant repurposing ECHOLOCATION, all on top of post-workout-odyssey brain-glee.

To which I say wow, thank you, and bravo, Jonathan, not to mention congratulations on one terrific debut!

CORE is an odd solve.

Yet again...

For those with an in-depth knowledge of golf (me), PGA, for short, refers to The PGA of America, an organization of club and teaching professionals.

Short for The PGA Tour, is "the Tour," which is an organization of professional golfers who compete on The PGA Tour.

So the correct answer in the golf world to "Tour overseer, for short" is "the Tour."

BTW, I have no problem arriving at the correct *crossword* answer to these mangled sports references.  My problem is that I do so by thinking, "what would someone clueless about XYZ Sport think is the correct answer?"

Otherwise, a great puzzle.  I had no clue SNEEERY was a word, and had no idea that the was a car in 1974 with airbags. I don't even remember seat belts in those days.

In 1999, we were buying a new car. Had our eyes on one particular model, and were set to buy it, but Consumer Reports advised, "If you are considering (this), test drive (that)". So we did. 

I loved that. And this was to be my car. So when the dealer asked me for my opinion, I said, "Well, it's nice, but...can it fit a 20 oz. WaWa?" He thought I was kidding, but not every car had cup holders at that time, and I picked up a 20 oz cup of WaWa coffee every morning on my way to work. The next morning, there was a message on my work voice mail. "It fits a 20 oz. WaWa." He had tried it himself on his way in to work. We bought the car.

I know many of you are wondering what the heck kind of a name WaWa is. WaWa is the name of a Pennsylvania town, and the convenience store's headquarters are located there, and obviously named for the town. The coffee is excellent, and it is a well-loved shop for all kinds of convenience items, including made-to-order (choose your term:) hoagies, subs, heroes, grinders. I lived in NJ at the time, and WaWa is all over there as well. Their gas stations used to be well-priced, too. Now, just like every one else. And that concludes today's lesson on WaWa.

But for something truly lovely, Maurice Ravel's Sonatina is in F-sharp, but the second movement, a menuet, is in [D-flat] major; here's an arrangement by the great harpist Carlos Salzedo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y5KEsXuoM24&list=RDy5KEsXuoM24&start_radio=1 Echo effect have been used in music for a long time. I was not raised to be religious, but my wife's (girlfriend at the time) family went to synagogue fairly regularly, so I got a touch of religion a long time ago.

I also studied ancient mythology in school, and at some point realized that these absurd stories were once someone's religion.  (A religion can be defined as humanity's way to try to fill in the gaps of understanding about the universe.)

Once I realized that, it wasn't a far jump to believe that there wasn't a talking snake and a magical tree in an otherwise perfect garden, a worldwide flood that left eight survivors, an Exodus which included a parted sea, etc.

As the universe is better and better understood, religion becomes less and less necessary for its understanding.  But it can be very comforting, so it continues to thrive in much of the world.

Sure, both Greek mythology and the Bible contain stories.  But calling them "story-telling" or "a storybook" seems incredibly reductionist to me.

commentBody:
@Sam Lyons
Welcome to Hebrew. All vowels in Hebrew appear as 'points' -- dots and bars adjacent to consonants. As you grow up, you progress to reading 'without points' -- i.e., without vowels. Rarely, a vowelless text may add a single vowel necessary to disambiguate a word's tense or mood. But once you're an adult, you read vowelless texts as a matter of course.

@Tim

This is an interesting point. Are you aware of "The Great Vowel Shift" that occurred in the English language centuries ago? I learned about this in my "History of the English Language" class.

I believe we are having another Great Vowel Shift now. Listening to the news, I hear almost every word with a sound that should be pronounced "blender" sounding like "blinder"--over and over. Have you noticed it?

I think also the influence of Spanish language speakers might be causing changes in pronunciation: these speakers don't distinguish it" and "eat" the way native speakers of English do.

@Al  in Pittsburgh no

You‚Äôve paused right before ‚ÄòExcursus on the Sense of Time,‚Äô is that right? (I looked to see but I wasn‚Äôt sure whether you were going by IA paging or the actual page numbers of the book.)

The tragedy of the words our predecessors leave behind is that even when relatively little time has passed‚Äîsay, a generation; four in the case of The Magic Mountain‚Äîso few stop to absorb the lessons. If more cared to look at how millions of Hans Castorps thought‚Äîand acted‚Äîat the precise moment in history Mann tackles, maybe we wouldn‚Äôt be barreling headlong into another disaster a mere century later. We leave behind words not just of our glories, but of our worst mistakes, always hoping that the generation that follows won‚Äôt repeat them. 

So yes, displaced and mutilated‚Äîand never seen for the caution they carry. 

You‚Äôve met Settembrini by now and, I believe Chauchat. I‚Äôm looking forward to your meeting Naphtha.

@Al in Pittsburgh Your comment reminds me of the days when the NYT had book discussion forums presided over by Mick Sussman. Nice to know he's still around. https://www.nytco.com/press/two-new-editors-for-standards-mick-sussman-and-tom-kaplan/

@Sam Lyons

  Yes, I've added some quotes from the Excursus in my notes on Han's character.  Probably won't fit in one reply.  Here are items 1-3:

1. Mann uses the word ‚Äúeinfachen‚Äù.  Dictionaries give simple, uncomplicated, and straight forward.  Translators give ‚Äúsimple-minded‚Äù [L-P] and ‚Äúperfectly ordinary‚Äù [Woods].  I will argue that his character in constrained by this place and time, but that he is in no way an ordinary man.   

2.  The Castorps are not aristocrats.  They have been of the merchant class since 1650, the first date etched on the family Christening Basin.  The six generations listed there have survived despite momentous changes in the outside world.  (The end of the 30 years war, the rise of Prussia under Frederick the Great, and the unification of Germany under Bismark).  Hamburg has remained a self-governing city-state.  His grandfather was a Senator in the local council.

3. I would describe Hans' character as constrained by middle-class morality and manners.

Parts 4-6 showing H's uniqueness to follow.

@Sam Lyons   Parts 4-6 on Han's character emphasizing his uniqueness. 

4.  He is an orphan.  He has lost mother, father, and guardian grandfather within the two and a half years before the age of eight.  We are told little of his education other than eight semesters at technical colleges ending at age 22.  He has ‚Äúnever met a literary man".  (I will find more when  I get to later chapters.  Spoiler: I've heard that the first appearance of ‚Äúthe pencil‚Äù will occur while he is away at boarding school.)

5. Some personal quirks:  He is angered by the slamming of doors and scandalized by the ‚Äúactivities‚Äù of the couple in the next room.  He says things like ‚ÄúI really like the sight of a coffin.‚Äù and ‚ÄúFunerals are more uplifting than church.‚Äù

6. .Whether the door slammed by Mme. Chauchat (hot cat) is a Freudian symbol of sexual rejection remains to be seen.

Enough for now.  Back to the book and working on notes for Space and Time.  Einstein's work on relativity, like Freud's psychoanalytics,  was published before the time of the novel and its writing.

Often, if they're writing for a specific singer or even a given register, it will depend on where the tessitura -- the strongest, most natural part of the singer's range --  falls.
